    Causal Survival Analysis

    Robin J. Evans

    Causal_Survival_Analysis.Rmd

    We begin by loading the library.

    library(survivl)

    Time-Varying Covariates

    If the treatment and covariates are allowed to be time-varying, then an ordinary Cox proportional hazards model will not have any causal interpretation. Instead we must use something like a Cox Marginal Structural Model (MSM) instead. This assumes that the set of observed covariates is sufficient to control for confounding at any given timepoint, and that the causal quantity of interest is the marginal effect of the treatment only on the outcome.

    We can simulate from such a model using a copula for the outcome and covariates. We select a normal covariate \(Z\), a binary treatment \(X\), and we must have an exponentially distributed outcome \(Y\). We also use a Gaussian copula.

    formulas <- list(list(),
                 Z ~ X_l1,
                 X ~ Z_l0,
                 Y ~ X_l0,
                 list(Y = list(Z~1)))
family <- list(integer(0), 1, 5, 3, 1)

    The parameters to be specified will depend upon the particular families used. Note that all the following distributions are conditional on \(Y_{t-1} = 0\). We take \[\begin{align*} Z_t \mid \overline{Z}_{t-1}, \overline{X}_{t-1} &\sim N(1 + X_{t-1}/2, \, 1)\\ X_t \mid \overline{Z}_{t}, \overline{X}_{t-1} &\sim \operatorname{Bern}(-1 + Z_t)\\ Y_t \mid do(\overline{X}_{t}) &= \mathbb{I}\{Y^*_t < 0\} \mid do(\overline{X}_{t})\\ Y^*_t \mid do(\overline{X}_{t}) &\sim \operatorname{Exp}(\exp\{1.1-X_t/2\}), \end{align*}\] and use a Gaussian copula with correlation \(2\operatorname{expit}(1) - 1 = 0.462\) between \(Z_t\) and \(Y_t^*\).

    pars <- list(Z = list(beta=c(1,0.5), phi=1),
             X = list(beta=c(-1,1)),
             Y = list(beta=c(1.1,-0.5), phi=1),
             cop = list(Y = list(Z = list(beta=1))))

    Now we create a survivl_model which contains all of our inputted information. To simulate samples from this MSM call the rmsm function.

    set.seed(123)
surv_model <- survivl_model(formulas=formulas, family=family,
                    pars=pars, T = 5,
                    link = list(character(0), "identity", "logit", "log"))
dat <- rmsm(n = 1e4, surv_model)
datl <- surv_to_long(dat)

    Fitting the Model

    Since this is a time-varying model, the obvious inference method is to use inverse probability weighting. We recommend using the survey library’s svyglm function, since its standard errors account for the re-weighting.

    library(survey)
library(dplyr)
library(ipw)
options(digits=5)

    Now, we fit a GLM to obtain the weighting to use with \(X\).

    # Fit model using inverse probability weighting


temp <- ipwtm(
  exposure = X,
  family = "binomial",
  numerator = ~ 1,
  denominator = ~ Z,
  link = "logit",
  id = id,
  timevar = t,
  type = "all",
  data = datl)

datl$wt <- temp$ipw.weights

    At this point we can fit the model to obtain the coefficients for the effect of \(X\) on \(Y\).

    glmY <- coxph(Surv(t, t_stop,Y)~ X, id = id, data = datl,
                               weights = datl$wt, timefix = FALSE)
summary(glmY)$coefficients
#>      coef exp(coef) se(coef) robust se      z   Pr(>|z|)
#> X 0.51371    1.6715  0.02168  0.027469 18.701 4.8175e-78

    Naïve Approaches

    If we ignore the fact that the covariates are time-varying, we will obtain a biased estimate of the coefficient of \(X\) on \(Y\).

    mod_naive <- svyglm(I(1-Y) ~ X, 
              family=binomial(link=log), 
              design = svydesign(ids=datl$id,
                                 weights=~1,
                                 data=datl))
summary(mod_naive)$coefficients
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value  Pr(>|t|)
#> (Intercept) -0.461192  0.0066474 -69.379 0.0000000
#> X           -0.029642  0.0099870  -2.968 0.0030042
